instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study to estimate soil organic matter (SOM) in desert soils?

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the related study to estimate soil organic matter (SOM) in desert soils?
Output: Particle swarm optimization (PSO), competitive adaptive reweighted sampling (CARS), and ant colony algorithm (ACO) were used as spectral feature processing methods in the related study to estimate soil organic matter (SOM) in desert soils.

instruction: How does the SNV spectral pre-processing method improve the accuracy of the estimation model for soil organic matter (SOM) content in desert soil using in situ spectroscopy?
Output:
The SNV (standard normal transform) spectral pre-processing method enhances the spectral information related to soil organic matter (SOM) and improves the accuracy of the estimation model for SOM content in desert soil using in situ spectroscopy. By applying the SNV method, the spectral data is normalized and transformed to have a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one. This normalization process helps to reduce the influence of external environmental factors, such as surface roughness of soil, changes in weather conditions, and atmospheric water vapor, which can interfere with the accuracy of in situ spectroscopy. 

The SNV method effectively enhances the spectral information related to SOM by reducing the variability caused by these external factors. This improved spectral information allows for a more accurate estimation of SOM content in desert soil. The study found that the SNV method was one of the most effective spectral pre-treatment methods in improving the accuracy of the estimation model.
